citations.narrative:
* A Fennec Fox named “Colonel” escaped while being exhibited at a private residence on or about 27-Oct-24. According
to the licensee, the escape happened during the handling process of putting the fox back into its traveling enclosure. An
employee was taking off the fox’s leash to put the animal back into its traveling enclosure and the employee tripped
slightly. The fox jumped out of the handler’s control and ran away from the handler. When asked if “Colonel” was found
the licensee stated no. The owner stated, the area of exhibition had numerous backyard fences which made it difficult to
locate and catch the fox after it escaped. The owner mentioned that they and employees searched numerous hours
looking for the fox. The owner also used a tracking dog, and live traps with bait for several days. However, they were
unsuccessful locating and capturing the fox. At the time of the inspection, the temperatures for the local climatic area were
upper 40’s during the day and upper 20’s during the evening. This temperature range poses a serious health risk for a
fennec fox that is not acclimated to temperatures around and below freezing.
Improper handling leading to animal escape can cause excessive cold distress, behavioral stress, physical harm and
unnecessary discomfort to the Fennec Fox.
Handling of all animals must be done expeditiously and carefully in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating,
excessive cooling, behavior stress, physical harm and unnecessary discomfort.
To be corrected by, 27-November-2024, and or for future handling of all animals.

* There was a raccoon at the very end of the main animal building that had a metal watering receptacle. This receptacle
had light to dark brown debris on the metal sides. Also, the water inside the receptacle was a dark brown color. The
licensee indicated that the receptacle had been cleaned last Saturday, prior to the inspection. The buildup of debris and
dark brown water indicates that the receptacle is not being kept clean and sanitary for the species and type of animal
involved and the frequency of adding fresh watering is not frequent enough. This is because Raccoons need fresh water
as part of their eat behavior. A water receptacle with a buildup of debris and dark brown water can potentially increase the
disease hazards for the one raccoon.
So all animals have fresh water, more frequent watering must consider species, age, condition and types of animals
involved. For the prevention of disease hazards, all water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary.
To be corrected by, 27-November-2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
* A Fennec Fox named “Colonel” escaped while being exhibited at a private residence on or about 27-Oct-24. According 
to the licensee, the escape happened during the handling process of putting the fox back into its traveling enclosure. An 
employee was taking off the fox’s leash to put the animal back into its traveling enclosure and the employee tripped 
slightly. The fox jumped out of the handler’s control and ran away from the handler. When asked if “Colonel” was found 
the licensee stated no. The owner stated, the area of exhibition had numerous backyard fences which made it difficult to 
locate and catch the fox after it escaped. The owner mentioned that they and employees searched numerous hours 
looking for the fox. The owner also used a tracking dog, and live traps with bait for several days. However, they were 
unsuccessful locating and capturing the fox. At the time of the inspection, the temperatures for the local climatic area were 
upper 40’s during the day and upper 20’s during the evening. This temperature range poses a serious health risk for a 
fennec fox that is not acclimated to temperatures around and below freezing.  
 
Improper handling leading to animal escape can cause excessive cold distress, behavioral stress, physical harm and 
unnecessary discomfort to the Fennec Fox. 
 
Handling of all animals must be done expeditiously and carefully in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, 
excessive cooling, behavior stress, physical harm and unnecessary discomfort.  
 
To be corrected by, 27-November-2024, and or for future handling of all animals. 
3.130 
   
Watering. 
* There was a raccoon at the very end of the main animal building that had a metal watering receptacle. This receptacle 
had light to dark brown debris on the metal sides. Also, the water inside the receptacle was a dark brown color. The 
licensee indicated that the receptacle had been cleaned last Saturday, prior to the inspection. The buildup of debris and 
dark brown water indicates that the receptacle is not being kept clean and sanitary for the species and type of animal 
involved and the frequency of adding fresh watering is not frequent enough. This is because Raccoons need fresh water 
as part of their eat behavior. A water receptacle with a buildup of debris and dark brown water can potentially increase the 
disease hazards for the one raccoon.

So all animals have fresh water, more frequent watering must consider species, age, condition and types of animals 
involved. For the prevention of disease hazards, all water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary.  
 
To be corrected by, 27-November-2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
